review_title: Independent ownership within a mission that changes lives
pros:
- impact impact impact! When your energy dips, you remember who you are reaching and pick back up
- global, diverse team. I now have buddies in countries all over Africa and have been over to visit more than once
- FAST PACED. This nonprofit is more rigorous, focused, and fast moving than the for profit places I've worked. You aren't signing up to snooze or sit on decisions, which was my big fear coming in
- very smart coworkers. analytic, well rounded, funny. it's a great crowd.
- comp is better than you'd expect and very transparent
cons: - work creep is an issue. You govern your own hours + PTO, but the engine is always running and it's hard to dip out.

pros:
- Employees are well valued,
- Everyone's voice is heard
- Good compensation benefits
cons: The organization implements independent working stile in each country, which made me feel little disorganized from my view.

review_title: GiveDirectly is a work in progress but has the makings of a wonderful org.
pros:
I gave this review a lot of thought and will try to share as balanced of a view as I can about what it's like to work here.

There are many positives to working at GD:

- People: as other reviews stated, the people at GD are brilliant and kind (often a rare combo). Even though everyone has a full plate, colleagues are happy to collaborate and support with projects outside the scope of their work, within reason of course. 

- Flat org structure: Leadership is accessible and good at sharing "air time" during meetings. My encounters with leadership have always been positive for the most part.

- Culture and values: GD takes its culture seriously. We have a "people" team that provides many opportunities to get staff input on initiatives and solicit feedback on culture. Though it's still a work in progress (see cons), I am heartened by the org's demonstrated commitment to building a strong, positive culture.

- Mission: GD's mission is AMBITIOUS and a real example of effective altruism. Our approach to putting recipients first and respecting their right to choose what they do with their cash is unlike many other similar orgs, and I wholeheartedly think it's the way to go.

- Salary is fairly competitive compared to other similarly-sized nonprofits
cons:
- DE&I/representation: There is a ton of work going on behind the scenes on moving the needle with respect to DE&I at the org. Staff participate in focus groups, the org has outlined clear goals, etc. That said, even though the majority of staff identify as Black and/or from the communities we serve, leadership unsurprisingly is mostly white. This has been acknowledged and I am eager to see more diversity and representation in leadership as the org grows.

- Burnout: Similarly, work at GD can be hectic and cut into other parts of life. Some managers/colleagues are really good at managing this and setting boundaries, but lots aren't. GD often takes stock of which staff members are feeling burned out, but it's not clear what's being done about it.

- Ambiguity: GD is more start-up-y than other traditional aid orgs, which is good if you like having a lot of ownership over projects and forging your own path. For others that might prefer more structure and preexisting systems, it might be a harder environment to adapt to.

pros:
•GD has grate values that I have carried and used even in personal life .
•Feedback culture that gives room for improvement .
• I love reaching out to the needy and I feel comfortable giving back with out expectations ,GD has it great .
•I have learnt alot while at Givedirectly ie working remotely ,in refuggee settlements ,and I love the interaction with new people and purported reciepients.
•Change in remuneration.
cons: •operating on short contracts,I would really love to work longer to impact more lives .

pros: You get to broaden your experience in the service space with enriching memories to grow professionally.
cons: It's hard with the partiality. There are three types of employees at Orange Liberia; the employees, contractors, and outsourcing agents. If you are not in the first two fits, it will be a tough journey for you. But it would be best if you persevered regardless.

pros:
1. Immense Learning and Development opportunities and growth opportunities
2. Open-door policy - Everyone regardless of title is approachable at GiveDirectly
3. The mission.
cons: Short and Intermittent contracts running for less than a year

pros:
Work from home flexibility

pros:
-You see the impacts of the program to recipients almost immediately
-Great team morale
-Socially flexible work environment
-They will give you everything you need to succeed in your work. And periodically ask you if you need more!
cons: The work is somewhat routine for a call center officer, but if you engage more with various recipients on program experience it tends to be less routine as every recipient has his/her own unique story

pros: I was a part of Eka's first Management trainee batch and past three years is filled with lots of learning & experience that comes with new challenges. Efficient training process, room for good opportunities & giving large responsibilities relatively early in the career are few amongst many pros.
cons: Not really a con but lack of transparency/layers of management can slow-down few processes.

review_title: Great work being done - but terrible staff support
pros: Very mission-driven. Always looking for a change to improve how they serve people. Innovations.
cons:
Zero respect for work-life balance. No support for staff in difficult conditions
Under-qualified senior staff 
Culture of "who shouts louder is heard"
High turnover rate and bad management of national contracts

pros: Best working conditions. Their salaries are highly competitive.
cons: Duration of contracts is short

review_title: Driven People, Supportive Culture, Bold Mission
pros:
1. The people: best part about GD, whole team wants peers to succeed, and everyone (even people on different teams) goes out of their way to support each other. people are goofy, hard working, and understanding 

2. The culture: supportive candidness is highly, highly valued. teammates give descriptive criticism AND praise so you can usually tell if you're aiming in the right direction. communication is never accusatory, always productive
cons: 1. Interviewing: didn't always know where I stood (i.e how many rounds remained, who I'd speak with, when I'd hear back from last interview)

pros: great added benefits for all staff
cons: nothing comes to mind at the moment. will update when I do

pros: Value employees give every employee an opportunity to share ideas.
cons: Takes time to respond, but eventually will always in the end
